newsitem.title: BELGIUM: EU monetary panel resumes work on EMU.
newsitem.headline: EU monetary panel resumes work on EMU.

text.p: The European Union's monetary committee reconvened for a second day of talks on Wednesday with the hope of breaking a deadlock over the details of a budget stability pact, sources said.
The group, comprised of national treasury and central bank officials, gathered late Tuesday and spent most of their time discussing Greece's economic convergence program.
While officials gave Greece high marks for the work it has done towards meeting the Maastricht treaty's economic criteria, it was encouraged to do more, sources said.
A budget stability pact and the European Commission's economic outlook for the EU is on Wednesday's agenda.

The meeting comes amid doubts over how much agreement there is on the details of a stability pact, designed to enforce budgetary rigour among governments taking part in European economic and monetary union (EMU).

Under the plan, governments running deficits in excess of three percent of total output would face an initial fine of 0.2 percent of GDP, with a further one percent of GDP penalty tacked on for every percentage point over the three percent threshold.
A maximum fine of 0.5 percent of output is envisaged.
EU monetary officials say Germany is expected to stand firm against a perceived watering down of its initial proposal.

In particular, Bonn is worried that governments might escape punitive sanctions should their economies suffer an economic downturn. A precise definition of what constitutes a recession is what Germany wants, sources said.
German officials also want the fine to be open-ended.
Officials now say agreement on a budget accord is unlikely before next year, with some expecting only a political declaration by EU leaders when they meet in Dublin on December 13-14.
Rounding out the session will be further work on a new Exchange Rate Mechanism, linking the single currency to countries on the perimeter of EMU, and legal issues regarding monetary union.
The results of Wednesday's meeting will form the basis for talks on EMU among EU finance ministers on November 11.
